intro: Acaena australis, commonly known as New Zealand burrweed, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and spiny bracts. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are typically clustered in dense inflorescences. Its fruit is a dry, hairy achene that often contains a single seed, and the plant is known for its ability to form dense mats in its native habitat. Acaena australis is adapted to a variety of soil types and can thrive in both full sun and partial shade.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena australis is primarily native to New Zealand. It is commonly found in the southern regions of the country, including the South Island and parts of the North Island. This plant thrives in a variety of habitats, such as grasslands, shrublands, and coastal areas. It is well adapted to the temperate climate and can tolerate both dry and moist conditions. Acaena australis plays an important role in the local ecosystem, providing food and habitat for various native wildlife species.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena australis was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there by European settlers during the 19th century. The plant was initially planted for ornamental purposes due to its attractive foliage and flowers. However, it has since become invasive, outcompeting native species in many areas. Its spread has led to concerns about its impact on local ecosystems and biodiversity.
